description.en:
This course covers the basic concepts and techniques of probability and statistics, starting with probability theory and Bayes' theorem. Students will also learn about diagnostic tests and how to apply them. The course then delves into types of data, including numeric and non-numeric data, and explores main descriptive statistics such as mean, standard deviation, and quartiles. Students will also learn how to choose proper visualization depending on the type of data (histograms, bar charts, and box plots).
The course then investigates random variables and discrete and continuous distributions. Students will learn about binomial, Poisson and normal distributions along with standard deviation and standard error, sample mean, prediction interval, and confidence interval. Students will learn how to compare means and percentages, and will be introduced to statistical hypothesis testing, including test statistics and p-values. 
The course will then explore two-sample t-tests, both paired and unpaired, and how to compare percentages in two populations. 
Finally, students will learn about the chi-square test, and measures of correlation. Throughout the course, students will engage in practical applications of these concepts to real-world problems, enabling them to apply basic statistical methods to analyze data and communicate their findings.
description.et:
This course covers the basic concepts and techniques of probability and statistics, starting with probability theory and Bayes' theorem. Students will also learn about diagnostic tests and how to apply them. The course then delves into types of data, including numeric and non-numeric data, and explores main descriptive statistics such as mean, standard deviation, and quartiles. Students will also learn how to choose proper visualization depending on the type of data (histograms, bar charts, and box plots).
The course then investigates random variables and discrete and continuous distributions. Students will learn about binomial, Poisson and normal distributions along with standard deviation and standard error, sample mean, prediction interval, and confidence interval. Students will learn how to compare means and percentages, and will be introduced to statistical hypothesis testing, including test statistics and p-values. 
The course will then explore two-sample t-tests, both paired and unpaired, and how to compare percentages in two populations. 
Finally, students will learn about the chi-square test, and measures of correlation. Throughout the course, students will engage in practical applications of these concepts to real-world problems, enabling them to apply basic statistical methods to analyze data and communicate their findings.

objectives.en: Develop practical skills in probability and statistics, preparing students for advanced courses. Enhance understanding of statistical terms in scientific literature and build critical reading, thinking, and basic statistical analysis abilities.
objectives.et: Develop practical skills in probability and statistics, preparing students for advanced courses. Enhance understanding of statistical terms in scientific literature and build critical reading, thinking, and basic statistical analysis abilities.

learning_outcomes.en: After passing the course students will have basic understanding of probability and statistics and also have enhanced their proficiency in transferable skills.
learning_outcomes.et: After passing the course students will have basic understanding of probability and statistics and also have enhanced their proficiency in transferable skills.

learning_outcomes.en:
Learning outcomes related to the subject:
-	Understand the concept of probability and its applications.
-	Explain Bayes’ theorem and its role in diagnostic testing and apply Bayes rule to real life problems.
-	Differentiate between numeric and non-numeric data.
-	Understand and calculate main descriptive statistics: (mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, median, quantiles)
-	Choose appropriate vizualisation based on the data type (pie chart, bar chart, histogram, boxplot, scatter plot)
-	Understand the concept of random variables.
-	Understand continuous distributions, particularly the normal distribution and its properties.
-	Apply properties of normal distribution for real life problems. Interpret the parameters of the normal distribution (mean and standard deviation).
-	Understand discrete distributions such as binomial and Poisson and utilize their useful properties in the real life problems. 
-	Construct confidence intervals for proportions and means.
-	Understand the need for statistical testing.
-	Formulate hypotheses, choose and apply appropriate statistical test and interpreting results.
-	Perform hypothesis testing for single proportion and difference of two proportions.
-	Perform hypothesis testing of the mean: one-sample t-test, paired data and independent samples.
-	Understand the chi-square test and its applications for testing independence in two-way tables and testing goodness of fit.
-	Understand the concept of correlation and measure of correlation.

learning_outcomes.en:
Learning outcomes related to transferable skills: 
-	Develop effective communication skills by actively listening, expressing ideas clearly, and resolving conflicts within a group setting.
-	Cultivate collaborative abilities, including team building, delegation, and understanding shared responsibilities.
-	Enhance problem-solving skills through brainstorming, analytical thinking, and adaptability when working with others.
-	Learn to allocate tasks efficiently, prioritize effectively, and meet deadlines as part of a team effort.
-	Gain leadership experience by taking charge when needed and motivating fellow team members.
-	Practice positive social interactions within a collaborative context.
-	Hone negotiation skills and influence others constructively during group decision-making.

Learning outcomes related to transferable skills: 
-	Develop effective communication skills by actively listening, expressing ideas clearly, and resolving conflicts within a group setting.
-	Cultivate collaborative abilities, including team building, delegation, and understanding shared responsibilities.
-	Enhance problem-solving skills through brainstorming, analytical thinking, and adaptability when working with others.
-	Learn to allocate tasks efficiently, prioritize effectively, and meet deadlines as part of a team effort.
-	Gain leadership experience by taking charge when needed and motivating fellow team members.
-	Practice positive social interactions within a collaborative context.
-	Hone negotiation skills and influence others constructively during group decision-making.

independent_work.en: Students will have the opportunity to earn up to 40% of total points from practical team-based learning (TBL) session and individual tasks. The final test will be worth 60% of the final grade and will cover all topics discussed throughout the course. It is mandatory for all students to participate in the practical sessions. In order to foster a collaborative and supportive learning environment, students will be assigned to teams by the lecturer at the beginning of the course. These teams will remain fixed throughout the duration of the course.
independent_work.et: Students will have the opportunity to earn up to 40% of total points from practical team-based learning (TBL) session and individual tasks. The final test will be worth 60% of the final grade and will cover all topics discussed throughout the course. It is mandatory for all students to participate in the practical sessions. In order to foster a collaborative and supportive learning environment, students will be assigned to teams by the lecturer at the beginning of the course. These teams will remain fixed throughout the duration of the course.

description.en:
In total, practical TBL sessions will count for 40% of the final grade. It is mandatory for all students to participate in the practical sessions and come prepared for the practicals. Attendance, participation, and contribution to the team will be taken into consideration when awarding points.

There is no opportunity to improve points earned from team-based learning sessions, except in cases where a student is absent due to illness or other extenuating circumstances and provides a doctor's note within one week to be eligible for additional questions on the final test to make up for the missed TBL session.
description.et:
In total, practical TBL sessions will count for 40% of the final grade. It is mandatory for all students to participate in the practical sessions and come prepared for the practicals. Attendance, participation, and contribution to the team will be taken into consideration when awarding points.

There is no opportunity to improve points earned from team-based learning sessions, except in cases where a student is absent due to illness or other extenuating circumstances and provides a doctor's note within one week to be eligible for additional questions on the final test to make up for the missed TBL session.

description.en: Students must earn at least half of the points available on the final test. The final test, worth 60% of the final grade, will cover all topics discussed throughout the course. The test will assess students' understanding of probability and statistics concepts, as well as their ability to apply these concepts to real-world problems.
description.et: Students must earn at least half of the points available on the final test. The final test, worth 60% of the final grade, will cover all topics discussed throughout the course. The test will assess students' understanding of probability and statistics concepts, as well as their ability to apply these concepts to real-world problems.

grade_preconditions.en:
The course will end with a test. Student needs to gain at least half of the points in the test. 

In the event that a student misses the final test due to illness or other extenuating circumstances, they must provide a valid doctor's note within one week to be eligible for a retake opportunity.
grade_preconditions.et:
The course will end with a test. Student needs to gain at least half of the points in the test. 

In the event that a student misses the final test due to illness or other extenuating circumstances, they must provide a valid doctor's note within one week to be eligible for a retake opportunity.

grade_evaluation.en:
To determine the final grade for the course, points earned in team-based learning sessions and individual assignments and the final test will be added together. The team-based learning sessions and individual assignment accounts for 40% of the final grade, while the final test accounts for 60% of the final grade (student must gain at least 50% of total points in the test). 

Bonus points (max 3) will be added to final result. 

In case a student fails to achieve the minimum passing requirement of 50% in the test on the first attempt, they will be allowed to retake the test. However, it is important to note that retaking the test will not be an option to improve the final grade beyond the minimum passing grade.
grade_evaluation.et:
To determine the final grade for the course, points earned in team-based learning sessions and individual assignments and the final test will be added together. The team-based learning sessions and individual assignment accounts for 40% of the final grade, while the final test accounts for 60% of the final grade (student must gain at least 50% of total points in the test). 

Bonus points (max 3) will be added to final result. 

In case a student fails to achieve the minimum passing requirement of 50% in the test on the first attempt, they will be allowed to retake the test. However, it is important to note that retaking the test will not be an option to improve the final grade beyond the minimum passing grade.

debt_elimination.en: The course provides an opportunity for students to write the test and, if needed, resit the test if they score less than 50% of the total points in the test. In case a student misses the initial test due to illness and a doctor's note is provided, the student will be allowed to take the test on a later date and retake it if needed. However, if a student fails to show up for the initial test and fails the resit, there will be no other options for retaking the exam.
debt_elimination.et: The course provides an opportunity for students to write the test and, if needed, resit the test if they score less than 50% of the total points in the test. In case a student misses the initial test due to illness and a doctor's note is provided, the student will be allowed to take the test on a later date and retake it if needed. However, if a student fails to show up for the initial test and fails the resit, there will be no other options for retaking the exam.
